titlestmt.titleproper: Finding aid for the Smith College collection of cuneiform tablets MRBC.MS.00044

editionstmt.p: This is a partial version of the full finding aid, and describes only the tablets that have been digitized. A complete listing of the cuneiform collection exists in paper form in the Mortimer Rare Book Collection.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2018-04-09 11:28:39 -0400.

did.unittitle: Smith College collection of cuneiform tablets
did.langmaterial: Each tablet is in the Sumerian or Semitic Babylonian languages of the Near East.
did.abstract: This collection of three hundred and seventy Babylonian clay tablets was excavated in Iraq. They are largely legal and business records. In addition to receipts for grain, beverages, animals, slaves, and silver, there are letters, pay-lists, contracts, sales, leases,loans, partitions for inheritances, and ancient labels or tags. Written between 2700 and 500 B.C., the cuneiform tablets document early Mesopotamian culture.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for use without restriction beyond the standard terms and conditions of Smith College Special Collections.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The bulk of this collection was transferred from the Smith College department of religion and Biblical literature to the Mortimer Rare Book Room on May 10, 1993. Two tablets were donated to the MRBC by Staunton Williams, Jr., in 2014.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: The tablets were probably excavated at sites in what is now Iraq and procured for Smith College by professors Irving F. Wood and Elihu Grant, beginning with twenty-three items in 1915.

otherfindaid.head: Other Finding Aids
otherfindaid.p: This online finding aid currently includes descriptions only for the four tablets that have been digitally imaged. The other 366 tablets are described in a paper finding aid, as well as various guides and study aids including translations for some tablets, which are available in the Smith College Special Collections.

Cyrus H. Gordon described some of the tablets in his publication Smith College Tablets: 110 Cuneiform Texts Selected from the College, (Northampton, Mass.: Published by the Department of History of Smith College, 1952). His transcriptions and any further information that is known about each tablet have been included in the printed finding aid in the Mortimer Rare Book Collection.

See also Cuneiform documents in the Smith College Library by Elihu Grant(Haverford, Pa. : [publisher not identified], 1918) which includes descriptions of tablets numbered 252-255 and 257-274 of the Smith collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection of three hundred and seventy Babylonian clay tablets, excavated in Iraq, are largely legal and business records. In addition to receipts for grain, beverages, animals, slaves, and silver, there are letters, pay-lists, contracts, sales, leases,loans, partitions for inheritances, and ancient labels or tags. Written between 2700 and 500 B.C., the cuneiform tablets document early Mesopotamian culture.
Each tablet is in the Sumerian or Semitic Babylonian languages of the Near East.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Each tablet has been assigned a unique number, and they are arranged in numerical order in the cuneiform cabinet.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The materials in this collection are in the public domain. Researchers need not seek or secure permission to re-use or reproduce materials.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Smith College collection of cuneiform tablets, Mortimer Rare Book Collection, Smith College Special Collections, Northampton, Massachusetts.
